abstract.p: CD has been elected a Corresponding Member of the Biology Section of the Académie Impériale des Sciences, St Petersburg.

keywords.term: Academie Imp. Sci. St.-Petersbourg, biology section

div.p: J’ai l’honneur de Vous informer que l’Académie Impériale des Sciences Vous a élu son membre correspondant dans la section biologique.

En Vous conférant ce titre, l’Académie a voulu Vous témoigner l’estime qu’elle professe pour Vos travaux et elle espère que Vous voudrez bien lui communiquer tout ce qui pourrait l’intéresser dans la branche que Vous cultivez avec tant de supériorité.

En Vous transmettant ci–près le diplôme d’usage, je me félicite, Monsieur, d’être en cette circonstance l’organe et l’interprète des sentiments de l’Académie et de pouvoir Vous offrir l’expression de ma considération la plus distinguée. | C. Vesselofski | Secrétaire Perpétu〈el〉

opener.seg: The Perpetual Secretary to the Academy To Mr Charles Darwin

div.p: I have the honour of informing you that the Imperial Academy of Sciences has elected you as its corresponding member in the biological section.

In conferring this title, the Academy wished to display the esteem that it has for your work, and it hopes that you will be so good as to communicate whatever might be of interest to it in the branch that you cultivate with such superiority.

In hereby transmitting the customary diploma to you, I congratulate myself, Sir, on being the organ and interpreter of the Academy’s feelings in this matter, and on being able to present my most distinguished respects to you. | C. Vesselofski | Perpetual Secretary

div.note: For a translation of this letter, see Correspondence vol. 16, Appendix I.
For a transcription of this letter in its original French, see part I: 6–7.
Vesselofski gives both the Julian (22 December) and Gregorian (3 January) dates.
For more on CD’s election as a corresponding member of the Imperial Academy of Sciences at St Petersburg, see Korneyev ed. 1977, pp. 248–51.
The diploma, dated 29 December 1867, is transcribed in Correspondence vol. 15, Appendix III.
